div.head: Gedanken zur Weltausstellung in London 1851
div.p: Foreword.

Anyone who, for 60 years, through more or less active involvement in the technical field, combined with observation of what has newly emerged in the areas of physics and chemistry, finds himself in the position of being able to make a comparison between what existed in 1791 and what presently exists in 1851, he must, in observing the progress made in this period relative to what happened in earlier periods of the same duration, be astonished, one might say dumbfounded, by what the world's fair in London presents to us this year; and one is compelled almost involuntarily to exclaim "Enough, now; stop at once, human spirit, to work as you do; repose, and savour, as well, the fruits of your so manifold endeavours, for everything is transitory, after all!" — But that
is the nature and the prerogative of the eternally prevailing human spirit, emanating from the Creator and moving through both passing and future generations, to produce again and again in greater perfection, or in some alternative way, what the ravages of time devour from the earthly. The glass palace, with its thousand glories, will disappear again from the Earth, leaving no trace of its existence, yet only to make way, once again, for something new. These simultaneously exhilarating and disheartening reflections by no means exclude the homage that must be paid to the present with its achievements and to this world exhibition, in particular; and I, whose record of it is contained in these pages (kept, admittedly, for frequent lack of time, sometimes only sparsely), do not regret this trip in the slightest; no one, however, should expect to find here an index or catalogue or, much less, a systematic description of even a fraction of the exhibits; this is simply my diary, the account I give to myself of how I spent my time. Illustrated and non-illustrated papers will provide enough coverage of the exhibition, without exhausting it, while my final verdict, after having observed
and repeatedly observed, is that one can describe, another can listen to or read the description, but will, insofar as I infer from my own experience, never have or be able to obtain a genuine impression of this extraordinary event, if he has not seen it for himself. — As satisfied as I am with the outcome of what I had hoped to see and saw, limited as it was to just a few things, and also with the verdict I reached on the small and inconspicuous things I sent to the exhibition, which I perhaps owe only to the circumstance that they were objects of a peculiar kind, I was even more satisfied with the results of my stay in London, as well as in Birmingham, Manchester and Sheffield, and some pages of my diary filled up in an interesting way that quite deeply imprinted in my memory for recollection, and I close the same with thanks to the Highest that only a few weeks before my seventy-ninth birthday, in full strength, I was able to undertake the journey to this remarkable island and to add these notes about it to those from earlier times.

Schaffhausen, 21 July 1852.Das Tagebuch wurde 1853 bei Murbach & Gelzer in Schaffhausen gedruckt.
I. C. Fischer.

div.head: Schaffhausen–Freiburg, 12. Juni 1851
div.p:
On June 12th, I left Schaffhausen at 1 o'clock in the afternoon, via Stühlingen and Lenzkirch, for Freiburg. Regardless of the weather conditions, the Höllenthal always remains a most fascinating natural phenomenon. The geognosist must ask himself what tremendous forces created this deep and vertical cleft to form the bed of the Treisam? — The most striking scenes are visible only on a moonlit night, as was the case today. How must it have been for the solitary wanderer in earlier times, as he left this yet uninhabited realm of shadows and entered, full of awe, the lowlands of paradise? — This, as did a little later the so daringly constructed and artificially perforated tower of the minster in Freiburg, which stood out just as peculiarly, and has defied the force of the elements in unshakeable solidity for almost a millennium, made an immense impression on me. The pyramids in Egypt do not withstand comparison, neither in craftsmanship nor in beauty, with this magnificent structure, which was born of the old German spirit. — These were my thoughts, more or less,
and with far fewer resources than we have at our disposal today, this miracle could be accomplished, as we stopped in front of the post office in Freiburg around 11 o'clock and took up our quarters for the night at the Engel, amazed to find no strangers there at all.

div.head: Freiburg–Mannheim, 13. Juni 1851
div.p: I say we, for I had as traveling companions two other Swiss, a worthy compatriot, Captain Hug, and Cantonal Councillor Ammann of Ermatingen, on whom the current President of France often called when he was still living in Gottlieben. On the 13th, they accompanied me on the rather monotonous journey from Freiburg to Carlsruhe, where we parted ways, as they also undertook an excursion to Frankfurt.

I had enough time in the afternoon to visit Director Ziegler and Mr. Kachel Currency Councillor. From the former, I learned of important developments that were to compel the member states of the German Custom's Union to raise tariffs on Switzerland, which, however, as clear as the reasons for this appear to be, are not being duly observed in Bern for reasons that cannot be discussed here. From the latter, I learned that the renowned Uhlhorn press for minting currency (which I had already seen in operation in Munich) was victorious at the London exhibition for its efficiency over the one displayed there by the excellent mechanic MaudsleyAls ausgezeichneter Mechaniker und Begründer des englischen Werkzeugmaschinenbaus gilt Henry Maudslay (1771–1831). Fischer bezieht sich hier sehr wahrscheinlich auf seine Söhne, die das Familienunternehmen nach dem Tod des Vaters weiterführten. Welchen der beiden Söhne Fischer hier meint, ob Thomas Henry Maudslay (1792–1864) oder Joseph Maudslay (1801–1861), kann nicht eruiert werden. that operated by a different system.
It was even viewed with pleasure by Queen Victoria and the Duchess of Nemours. At 4 o'clock, I left again by train for Mannheim, visited Mr. Eisenhardt there, and after dinner at the Teutschen Hof, wrote these lines.

div.head: Mannheim–Köln, 14. Juni 1851
div.p: The 14th. Although there is much to enjoy about a journey on the Rhine by steamboat from Mannheim to Cologne, owing to the ever-changing and remarkable view of the shoreline in fine weather, which not only permits a stay on the deck but even invites one to do so, it becomes rather tedious when one is confined to the cabin or the so-called salon by cold, storm or rain, as was the case today in contrast to yesterday's beautiful, warm, though somewhat windy day. Also, for me at least, there was no one to engage in instructive or interesting conversation among the few educated passengers, so I was able to recover some sleep, which I had lost the two previous days by going to bed late and getting up very early; we arrived in Errata aus Erstdruck. Cologne at 7 o'clock in the evening, where I took up my quarters at the Kölnischer Hof.

div.head: Köln–Ostende, 15. Juni 1851
div.p:
The 15th. Today was far more interesting to me, with respect to various observations, than was yesterday, though the speed of the journey by rail hardly allows for the observation of any objects
outside it. — I was attracted, first, by the generally so very sectioned terrain, and then by the excellent cultivation of the soil, the further along one progresses, until finally entering Flanders. The horticultural crops, particularly the vegetables, seem to be far more advanced than our own, but even more interesting to me was the number of factories of all kinds, whose existence, as in England, is indicated by the high chimney stacks, and also by the numerous shipments of cast iron and steam engine parts, as well as by the quantity of zinc ores and the pure zinc derived from them.

There may come a time when the discovery will be made why zinc has not become wholly iron, or iron, in a given case, has not become either copper or zinc, since I have much reason to believe that the primary matter of these three metals is one and the same — A hypothesis about this, if it were in itself as simple as nature in its workings, could perhaps make one ridiculous, and yet I want to cite a case that would seem to give some support to my conjecture. As is well known, iron and copper, especially when they are melted together in fairly equal quantities, do not combine even in the highest flux, but instead, regardless of whether the mixture is poured into moulds or allowed to cool in a crucible,
separate distinctly from one another like oil and water, and only a small percentage, due to stoichiometric relationships, is absorbed by one from the other, yet the essential character of both metals remains. However, I had already accomplished this bond in various ratios in 1814, and I made it known under the name "yellow steel" in the diary of my trip to England in 1814, published in 1816 by H. Remigius Sauerländer in Aarau.

If one did not know that this was a metal compound, or so-called alloy, one might say: it is not iron, because it has a yellow colour and a different specific gravity, while another might say: but it is also not copper, because it is yellow and is drawn by a magnet like iron, and it is also not gun metal, and not brass, because, when thrown red-hot into water, it becomes hard, almost like steel. However, the art to the formation of this metal, which I will call a, is to add something that is lacking in each of the two individual substances; if that something, or these new basic elements, were not added, ♀ + ♂ would not = a, and so iron will neither become copper nor zinc, nor will zinc become iron, if these essential additives, which enable their transformation, are missing. As I should have noted at the outset, my better understanding Errata aus Erstdruck. in the meantime
has led me to believe, in contradiction with general opinion, that these metals are not simple bodies, though I readily admit that my above hypothesis concerning the existence of multiple basic elements of these metals does, indeed, have its weaknesses. However, the fact itself, of transference from one matter into another, still remains, and as long as we do not know the manner of formation of the metals, the bonding agent of their various atoms and the stoichiometric relationships necessary for this purpose, the dispute as to whether they are simple or compound will remain unresolved.

With these thoughts, not knowing how better to occupy my time on the train, I arrived at the station in Ghent, where the immensely light, yet solid construction of the two buildings whose columns of great height and width are made entirely of iron and whose roofs are composed only at the bottom of a single band of zinc and, then, up to the top, entirely of glass, captivated my full attention, so that I also invited my two traveling companions, who arrived with me in Cologne from Frankfurt, to view this graceful and peculiar building. — I wondered, is it the case, here, that the architect of this station in GhentErrata aus Erstdruck., earlier, and Paxton, who built the Glass Palace in London, later, had similar ideas without knowing of one another; as Newton and Leibniz, where,
while the former invented his fluxions, the latter founded the doctrine of calculus infinitorum?

I had continued to hope that it would still be as before that a steamboat would leave Ostende, where we arrived in the evening after 7 o'clock, for Dover the following morning, so that I could get a full night’s rest instead of the few hours I had slept the previous three nights, especially as I was, in fact, still a kind of convalescent, and my doctor had, perhaps only semi-voluntarily, released me from his care to make this strenuous journey. Alas, it was to be a true night of suffering, such as I had never experienced on my frequent sea voyages. It had been windy all day, but towards evening it became much stronger and mixed with rain. After a short dinner in Ostende, my two travel companions and I boarded the Royal Mail Steamship, which, according to a new schedule, sets sail every evening at 10 o'clock. We had taken our places on the first available seat or in the salon, and as long as the ship was still in the harbour, the passengers passed to and fro, there might have been 20 to 24 of them, and all were in good spirits. In the meantime, I delighted in the small round windows, of which there were only five on either side along the entire length of the salon and which resemble those on our Schaffhausen steamship to a hair's breadth, spreading in the daytime
just the same pleasant darkness so beloved by the English in their meditations and which might well inspire us to meditate too: yet, alas, it was to be otherwise. No sooner were we at sea than the violent swaying of the ship and the jolts made it clear that it was quite unsafe out there, and those with more sensitive natures soon began to suffer from seasickness in its full, ravaging form. My fairly good constitution withstood it for a long time, however, with the swaying of the ship, which became more violent from hour to hour, combined with repulsion at the effects of this disease, which is similar to cholera for its rapid spread among the passengers lying about in every direction, and their groaning and moaning, I could no longer endure it, and I do not recall ever having suffered so much during the at least four-hour duration of it.

div.head: Ankunft in Dover, 16. Juni 1851
div.p:
On June 16th, Mr. Hug, who could no longer bear to remain in the salon, which looked more like a death chamber, remained on deck from 3 o'clock in the morning on, despite the storm and rain, and today he reported to me, as we recounted our tales of woe, which even afterwards imposed on us a strict diet, that in that same hour the waves had become so high that they sometimes reached the helmsman at his post, who then quite phlegmatically shook the water off his coat of Indian rubber. After 9 o'clock in the morning (the steamboat was unable to land at low tide,
so remained on the high seas), we were picked up by smaller boats, and soon after were able to have our belongings, of which the night bags were not inspected at all, and the suitcases only superficially, taken to the inn. As a comment on the fact that nothing, not even misfortune, can be had cheaply in England, I will add that the waiter on the steamboat, who had the courtesy to provide the victims of the disease with the necessary basins, of which there was at most one, for every two persons, was paid 1 shilling or 36 kr.. of our money per person; then it cost another 36 kr. per person to get from the steamboat, which should have but failed to taken us, to shore on the other boat, and finally I had to pay 36 kr. to the porter, who carried my suitcase and the night bag to the inn, which was only the third house from the customs office.

If, by chance, anyone should be bored by this tale of woe, which my two aforementioned traveling companions will confirm word for word, then rightfully so, for so too am I. Only once was I compelled to laugh in the midst of all the misery, when the thought occurred to me, if only a skilled caricaturist were at hand to depict all the posturesErrata aus Erstdruck. and expressions of this heap of suffering humanity with the brush of a Hogarth. —

Of the ladies on board there is nothing to be said. The door to their salon remained closed, as is only proper; certainly, however, there will have been no lack of genuine sentimentality among them. Somewhat restored at the inn in Dover with Mr. Hippgrave, after having written a letter home and inviting them to join me, I walked around the town with my two traveling companions to see if they were satisfied by the first impression this, one might say in some respects, wonderland had made on them.

Aside from the picturesque setting of Dover, we admired the lavishly decoratedErrata aus Erstdruck. stores and the generally accomplished works displayed therein, and lastly, the inviting seaside resorts, so appropriately designed. Weary from the previous night's events, and weary from writing, I will retire for the day.

div.head: Dover–London, 17. Juni 1851
div.p: June 17th. After a delightful night's sleep, and some notes taken after breakfast, I left for London by rail at a quarter past 9 o'clock.

Inside the barbarous wooden boxes of the second-class carriages, which reveal this island's ferociously speculative spirit, we were joined by two Englishmen and the daughter of one of them, a young woman of about 14 years of age. Her father told me that she had already been with
relatives in Germany for 6 years and spoke German, which was, indeed, the case and superbly so. I have often remarked that children learn foreign languages much quicker than adults do, though the mental powers of the latter are more developed. Whoever wants to teach his children the knowledge and practice of other living languages at an early age should rather employ child caretakers and maids (the so-called governesses are usually too precise and, at least in their imagination, too learned) as teachers of those foreign languages than a professor with hisErrata aus Erstdruck. syntax and grammar, who has perhaps been torturing students with it for thirty years, and yet cannot himself speak any of the languages he teaches.

My two traveling companions were pleased to be able to converse with her, and through her with her father, who, as he informed me, was a landowner in York but lived in London. He was a highly educated and well-travelled man, spoke French and GermanErrata aus Erstdruck. in addition to his mother tongue, and perhaps it is due to the fact that I conversed with him in all three languages, in turn, that when I took leave of him at the train station in London, he pulled out his wallet and presented me with his visiting card, which read, "Mr Minet, 19, Old Quebeckstreet, Oxfordstreet, near the marble arch,"
together with an invitation to certainly pay him a visit. While the invitation from an Englishman who hardly knew me was extraordinary to me, I will accept it.

In the hustle and bustle of collectingErrata aus Erstdruck. our baggage, which is not assigned numbers as in Germany, and for which, even if heavy and numerous, one never pays anything, I lost my two traveling companions, who, by the way, had to take a completely different route to their lodging than I did to mine.

Upon arriving at the same, St. Paul's Family Hotel, St. Paul's Churchyard, I certainly would not have been given a room, since there has been another owner there for 4 years now, if the head waiter had not fortuitously recognized me straight away and promised to find me a room in the house, or elsewhere if no one left, by evening. Since it was barely 1 o'clock, and dinner is not until after 4 o'clock, I went to Newgate Street to visit the ironmonger Mr. FennBeide Brüder, Samuel und Daniel Fenn, hatten ihr Geschäft an der Newgate Street. Es ist unklar, welchen Herrn Fenn Fischer besuchte., with whom I had already become acquainted in 1794, when I was then working for Mr. Rhé, a mechanic in London, but did not find him at the shop, and bought various things for my wardrobe, which I had not wished to carry with me from home.

div.head: Das Ausstellungsgelände: Erster Eindruck, 17. Juni 1851
div.p:
After dinner I immediately boarded an omnibus to be taken for 18 Kr. (this is the fare from the area where I am staying)
to the exhibition building in Hyde park, a little over 6 English miles away: — not to go inside, but only to get a first impression of its position, circumference, style and execution, so that it would be independent of the interior, as the soul of the entirety. I was convinced that this impression must be different from the one conveyed by drawings, since the latter encompass neither foreground nor background, just as little as the side walls, of any importance to convey the proper scale of the whole, which even a linear scale, incidentally, would not provide. I have just had an idea, and at the end of this volume, I will attempt to establish a scale, at least for the citizens of my beloved hometown, that will produce a fairly accurate estimate of the extent of this building, and that will make the numbers comprehensible.

It was interesting to see the crowd walking to and fro, since it was already about 7 o'clock in the evening. Riding, it would seem, is fashionable again among the women; I observed several, each accompanied by her cavalier, riding up and down the avenue along the New river side; they wore dark blue long riding dresses, and, as if by agreement, small round felt hats, like the so-called "Hecker hat", though I believe, as daughters of Eve, their thoughts under these hats are less revolutionary than lustful. The calmness and decency among this crowd was remarkable, and it did not seem to me at all that I had seen any arrested expressions as those that appear in Paris on the eve of a revolution, or after it has already broken out.
The police are not at all bothersome; one is pleased to see them, as they are not mouchardsFranz. umgangssprachlich für «Spione»., but rather polite and eager to serve. The gaslights were already beginning to burn in the stores, which prompted me to return to my lodging to write the foregoing and retire for the day at 11 o'clock in the evening.

div.head: Fischers erster Ausstellungsbesuch, 18. Juni 1851
div.p: The 18th. At the usual time in London, namely after 10 o'clock in the morning, I commenced my daily business, visited Mr. Howard and Kreeft, Mr. Im Thurn and Mr. Faraday, for whom, since he had gone out, I left my card, and then went from there to the exhibition, where I stayed until 6 o'clock in the evening.

From the outside, as I already thought to myself yesterday, the building did not make the extraordinary impression on me that I had expected, and the reasons for this are as follows: first, for its immense length, it has no corresponding height, though the transept from the ground to the highest point of the semicircular vault measures 108 English feet. In this case, however, it was wise to concentrate on the special requirements of the situation, rather than follow standard protocol. Secondly, due to its proximity to the trees and its somewhat low position, the building cannot be viewed as a whole. Yet, upon entering, one has no choice but to be astonished by the very idea of it. How so many nations of the world, and in such different ways, have paid homage to it, and how these various displays,
despite their variety of material and form, have been so judiciously united into a whole — and to think that all this, including the colossal structure itself, was erected in such an incredibly short and strictly defined period. It would be a conceited, one might say quite ridiculous, undertaking to describe even a few of these multitudinous objects in any detail. The catalogues, public newspapers, and men of letters who have already written about this subject, or who will write about it in the future, say enough on this subject. However, one item particularly attracted my attention today, whose beauty must certainly be admired by all, and whose absolute uniqueness — namely the fountain, which, by my estimation, has a height of 30 feet, all parts of which are made of the most beautiful crystal glass, weighing almost 90 centners, and over whose uppermost bowl or basin the water falls, first, as a large veil and then, further down, in beautiful cascades, which, in the absence of flowing water, can be immediately transformed into the most dazzling and largest candelabra in the world. There are several other fountains of various kinds in the building, including one whose stone basin measures 36 feet in diameter, yet in these immense spaces is neither disruptive or conspicuous.

The second thing that captured my attention for some time
were the wax figures, life-size and adorned with their ornaments, of an Indian and his wife from the primeval forests of Amerika, the redskins, as they are called. Such a race of humans still exists, in contrast to those of the most advanced culture. One recognizes at first sight that they are quite faithful reproductions, and without being a Lavater, one sees in the exceedingly pronounced features, hardened by toil, exertion, and even the highest indifferentism, a coarseness, cruelty, and then again languor, and yet they too are human beings!

I note only in passing that in no country in the world would it have been possible to compile such a collection of the most remarkable things that the savage, semi-savage and highly civilized peoples have produced in art and craftsmanship, as is the case here. — Anyone who has seen this exhibition will carry the impression of it with him for the rest of his life, yet one must never expect anything but a fragmentary account of it.

Around 7 o'clock in the evening, I went to supper in a neighbouring, very nice dining establishment, where many of the gentlemen and ladies who had also come from the exhibition were present in several rooms, and lived, while enjoying everything in equal quality, 50 percent cheaper than in my hotel, which is located in the city, where everything is much more expensive.

div.head: Fischers zweiter Ausstellungsbesuch, 19. Juni 1851
div.p: June 19th. After having gone early in hopes of visiting Dr. Bolley and Mr. Colladon, our two Swiss commissioners at the exhibition (both staying in Finsbury Square, a place, in fact, for its great distance from the exhibition hall not at all convenient for the duties of their office) and encountering neither, I was given a warm and cordial reception by England's first chemist, Mr. Faraday, at the Royal Institution, and I was amply compensated for the long journey from Finsbury Square, where the above-mentioned compatriots are staying, to Albemarle Street Picadilly by the most fascinating conversation I had with him.

After almost an hour of discussion concerning primarily metallurgical and pyrotechnical objects, as well as the articles I had sent to the exhibition in response to a request I had received at home, I returned to the exhibition, which was not very far away (about half an hour). The thousands of echoes from the newspapers of all civilized countries will, without ever being able to exhaust the subject itself, describe it. I have already said how ludicrous it would be for a single individual to attempt anything remotely of the sort, and so I shall not, however many times I should go there, comment at all at length on what I have seen and admired.

Today I devoted myself first and foremost (it is forgivable for a father) to the search in the Austrian department for the submissions made by two of my sons who are established in that beautiful country, so richly endowed with natural treasures of all kinds.

Mr. Georg Fischer of Hainfeld delivered six tableaux of the most diverse assortment of files of cast steel and a seventh of samples of cast steel rods, the quality of whose shape, cut and grade is to be judged by the jury at a later point in time, and Mr. Berthold Fischer of Traisen, an exceptional collection of articles from the field of "malleable Castiron," which, though manufactured in England earlier, albeit under a veil of secrecy, I also invented, and for which I was once awarded exclusive privilege in 1829 by His Majesty the Emperor Francis. These articles of malleable cast iron were complemented by a number of beautifully crafted spindles for spinning mills from his factory. On my remark to one of the custodians, who are distributed throughout the building in small offices, that the labels ("tikets"), that is, the small plates bearing the name of the exhibitor and the number assigned to his products in the catalogue, were missing, I was given permission with the greatest generosity to add anything I should think appropriate in this regard myself. However, since these articles
had been placed under Austrian protection, I thought it appropriate not to preempt but to inform the I & R Commissioner, Mr. v. Buschek, of the matter by letter.

Altogether, one notices a great obligingness towards all strangers everywhere, and especially among the police, as well, and how so much attention is paid to everything without one being aware of it. The following may serve as evidence. Among the articles in my shipment to the exhibition, of which I had an illustration made at home by Mr. Beck, the drawing teacher, an engraving of which I commissioned in steel, there were also two daggers of meteoric steel of very beautiful Damask. Upon looking after my things at the exhibition, these daggers, which had been placed in a rather exposed location, had gone missing.

I was nearly convinced that they had vanished, and so I inquired with an official. The latter immediately sent a policeman to another official, who, as would be the case, had been entrusted with the supervision of the articles of the Swiss department. He arrived forthwith and retrieved them from behind a large piece of meteoric steel, where they had been placed for greater security. They were then given a more suitable place for viewing.

Thousands and thousands of objects, each of them peculiar in its own way, remain unobserved, depending on the character of the observer,
yet, for one thing the industrious and ingenious country of England has compelled the attention of every visitor, and this is that in which it also claims highest rank in the world, namely, the quantity of its curious machines; they produce all manner of things before the spectator's very eyes. Here, they artfully weave beautiful and complex designs. There, they print; there, they spin; there, hundreds of the most sensible machines and tools are displayed, all designed to save time and serve perfectly the needs of life, agriculture, luxury and the arts, and in the very midst of these various machines, at the side of a fountain, of which there are many in the building, in general, providing ample water for cooling and drinking, a millstream rushes in perpetual flow from the opening of an upright parallelepiped (tall narrow box), as if from a monstrous gullet, 10 feet high, and in a width of approximately 6 feet, into a relatively large basin. One cannot see where the water comes from, one cannot see where it goes, like the Danaids' barrel, the basin never fills. I wondered why, so as to make the whole thing still more imposing, they had not enclosed this surprisingly prosaic box with planks of imitation rock? In Frankreich, where they well-versed in the wrapping of everything in a pleasing manner, they would certainly
have done something of the sort, and in Italy, where they still delight in miracles, they would perhaps even have added a Moses with a staff. The English have not yet reached the zenith of figurative poetry. According to my calculation, I had covered eleven English miles on foot between 9 o'clock in the morning and after 5 o'clock in the evening on my long walks, and now faced the bleak prospect of making yet another considerable journey to the city, as all the carriages from the exhibition building were occupied. At the far end of Picadilly, I was fortunate enough to be able to occupy a seat vacated by another passenger on an omnibus, and to have my highly afflicted body brought to my lodging, to finally have supper at about 7 o'clock, and to write down the foregoing ruminations.

div.head: Über das Leben in London, 20. Juni 1851
div.p:
June 20th. The big cities are, with few exceptions, unpleasant and ruinous for those condemned to spend their entire lives there; they are veritable dungeons! Happy is he who is permitted to pass his days in honourable employment in our beautiful fatherland! — Londoners are never, or only very rarely, smiled upon by a sky as clear as our own, or rather, nearly the whole year through, they see nothing but the pall of smoke and dust spread so abundantly and vaporously over the metropolis. They do not behold the beautiful meadows, the running brooks, the green
forests, much less the silver crown of our Alps! — Grey and black-brown rows of houses without end, the ceaseless sound and noise of innumerable carts, laconic conversation or complete silence in the dining rooms of inns and even common taverns, where each of the arrivals first looks around in search of an unoccupied table, and as quickly as possible barricades himself behind an excessively large newspaper. This is but a brief, and certainly unexaggerated, sketch of London life, on the whole. — The bright side of all this, however, is that they are far more for domestic life than their neighbours across the channel, and that their quietude, and the spirit of study and advancement thus cultivated, applied even to the most inconspicuous of things, renders them capable of the astonishingly great things which they have already accomplished, and continue to accomplish. To these thoughts and comparisons, I was prompted by the various activities of the day, which I began and ended with difficulty, though it became interesting enough to me through an encounter with a steel manufacturer from Newcastle upon Tyne. I could not go to the exhibition, nor to the Chinese collection, which is not far from it, and made no other acquaintance than that of the banker where I withdraw the money I need, and much is needed, indeed. It is good to have earned it in advance.

div.head: Der «Fünf-Schilling-Abend», 21. Juni 1851
div.p:
June 21st. After a few outings very early in the morning, that is, in these late summer days at half past 7 o'clock, when most shops are still closed and there are not very many people or carriages on the street, I went to the counting house of the bank Paynes & Smith, for which I had received a cheque (payment order) of L. 30 yesterday, so that if someone else should present it for payment, I would not be obliged to honour it. However, only a few subordinates were there, who undertook to carry out my request, but told me that I would have to come back at 9 o'clock, as payments would not be issued until such time. The situation was as follows: The night before, while I was away, my tailor came to collect my coat for altering, however, in that very coat was my purse containing the cheque. I did not return home that evening until after 9 o'clock, by which time there was nothing I could do. This morning, after leaving the bank, I went directly to the fabric shop where I knew the tailor was working. — If, said the owner, the purse was in your coat, you will certainly get it back and whatever may be in it, upon which he went immediately to the tailor himself and brought back the purse and its contents in no time at all. In London, there is much deceit, but also much honesty, I believe more of the latter than of the former. In this city, the drink in particular makes
people poor and unhappy. The latter among all classes.

Regarding punctuality in all those businesses where, to a certain extent, mathematical precision prevails, which certainly has its advantages, I would like to add that when I returned to the bank a little before 9 o'clock, I was asked to take a seat on a bench opposite the table at which the five cashiers conduct their business. About five minutes before 9 o'clock, the official to whom I was to present the payment order arrived. I held it in my hand and showed it to him, but he said not a word. Instead, he emptied several sacks of gold into a drawer together with the familiar shovel used to scoop it out again, and did nothing more.

At the stroke of 9 o'clock, however, he asked me only, Do you prefer gold or banknotes? I replied gold. Without even counting (there were whole and half sovereigns), he poured the gold into the pan and out of it onto the table without taking any further notice of me. I counted it anyway, and it was quite correct. — In order to know where Professor Wilson's office in the glass palace (one could not have chosen a better name) might be, I asked a "policeman" when I arrived there where I might find it, and he pointed me to a completely different, very distant side of the building. I found it
all right, but did not encounter the man himself. About half an hour had passed since I decided to go home, when a police officer approached me quite some distance away from the spot. I thought to myself, What does he want? You have not done anything unlawful, after all. Then he stopped me and asked politely if I had found the office, to which I replied that I had, but this was proof to me of how carefully they observe people, for I was dressed in English style, that is to say in black. From him I first learned that the exhibition would remain open until the end of October, which I was glad to hear, since two of my sons, who are established in Austria, were also planning to visit England later. I have already said how humble and polite these "policemen" are. They are all handsome, well-chosen people with dark blue tail coats, on the collar of which is embroidered the number under which the officer is registered, dark blue pantaloons, fine round hats, white gloves and, under their arm, a rolled-up overcoat of "Indiarubber (caoutschouc)" for dubious weather, but neither tobacco pipe nor sabre, nor moustache. Well acquainted with the great city, or at least with the district assigned to them, anyone unsure of his bearings can obtain better information from no one, which they willingly give, even accompanying you for a distance, provided
that you speak English. — Today, being Saturday, the entrance fee, instead of 1 shilling, was now 5 shillings, like all Fridays and Saturdays. The rooms, however, were quite empty and, as I noted earlier, realized that, just as those less fortunate, richer people can grow equally accustomed to paying only a shilling for the same thing rather than five.

I remarked something else on this five-shilling evening, which was attended almost exclusively by people in equipages, in proof of the great backward stride of the English in complying with the spirited catechism of the radicals. They still remain devoted to the so-called "Zopfthum" (whether this scurrilous term is of German or Swiss origin I do not know) among the general public in their country, by holding on to the good things from earlier times that have been recognized by experience, without making their eradication a popular idea to the general population, which then has the good fortune to be declared emancipated for the moment, in the form of brass music and chorale singing.

div.head: Ein erfüllter Sonntag mit Schreiben, 22. Juni 1851
div.p:
June 22nd Today, being Sunday, I began writing early, having stopped yesterday owing to genuine fatigue. Later I walked through the beautiful, rather extensive, Cheapside, and would have liked to go into a "Coffeeroom" for a glass of ale or claret, but apart from the fact that all the stores were hermetically sealed, so too were the doors. Even at my inn, the exterior door
was closed, and only those who knew the secret could open it by turning the knob, otherwise one had to ring the bell. Returning to the inn, I asked the innkeeper, since I was in the habit of paying by the day, to bring me the bill, but he politely asked me to wait until morning. Whether this is the case at all inns, or whether he is some kind of sectarian, I do not know, but I do know that on the mainland they are more willing to take whatever money falls into their hands, they are not so particular about it, so as not to deter visitors. However little the Sabbath observance is to be despised, but rather to be honoured in the highest degree, if it comes from a sincerely thankful heart, where then every day becomes a Sabbath day, Christ Himself taught us the best lesson about it, when the Pharisees, whom those of our days resemble to a hair's breadth, asked Him for His opinion on it. An English woman spoke very earnestly to me about the fact that Parliament allows omnibuses and cabs ("cabriolets") to drive around town on Sunday and that railroads are allowed to operate, citing the God-fearing principles that have been practiced in her family, in that, when her dear father died and the funeral took place on a Sunday, the body (one does not carry it in England, one drives it to the churchyard) was not conveyed by her own horses, but by
hired ones. — I thought to myself, so it is they who are compelled to commit the sin of desecrating the Sabbath to spare her own from punishment. — In a province neighbouring the canton of Schaffhausen, one often sees painted on the farmhouses a burning house, and St. Florian in immense proportions beside it with a bucket of water, which he pours over the flames. Beneath one such painting, a jester wrote, "O great, holy Florian, save my house, set others on fire." — Is that not a fitting passage for this story?

I spent the rest of the day writing to my youngest son Berthold, who, like his two older brothersGemeint sind Wilhelm Fischer (1803–1882) und Georg Fischer (1804–1888)., has also earned his living and reputation in Austria through diligence and skill. For all three of them, the Horatian saying "Ubi bene, ubi patria"Eigentlich «Ubi bene, ibi patria» (Wo es mir gut geht, da ist meine Heimat). Das Zitat wird nicht Horaz, sondern Cicero zugeschrieben. remains true to this day, even though the true Swiss man, in almost all cases, is drawn back to his birthplace in later years. Among other things, I told him in my letter: "Yesterday I visited my old inn, where I used to live, Cross Keys, Wood Street, Cheap Side, and the alley, Shoe lane, Fleet Street, where I worked for the mechanic Rhé 57 years ago." — London does not change the way other cities do, it merely grows larger. Its brick houses always remain black, sad and monotonous; — Everything in the
world has two sides! England has its exhibition of industrial diligence, which is temporary, and we have that, which nature in so manifold a way and in ever-renewing beauty, spreads out before us in all the glory of its creative power.

div.head: Fischers vierter Ausstellungsbesuch, 23. Juni 1851
div.p:
June 23rd. This morning, in the interest of my son, Mr. Georg Fischer in Hainfeld, I wrote a letter to the Austrian commissioner in question, Mr. v. Buschek, to acquaint him with the matter and to ask for redress, as a truly significant error had taken place regarding his submission to the exhibition, both with regard to the omission of the display in the official catalog and in the name of the exhibitor on the objects themselves. Afterwards, I visited Mr. Im Thurn and Mr. Kreeft on private business. In the course of our conversation, we came to speak of a Mr. Spencer of Newcastle upon Tyne, with whose son I had become acquainted a few days ago, and he told me that he had recently won his case for the patent on spiral springs vs. cylinder springs, for the so-called buffets on locomotives, which, following the sale of his patent right to five other persons, secured him an annual income of L. St. 1900, or about fl. 23,000 of our money. Only in England are inventions, the offspring of observation,
contemplation, and experiment to attain certainty, so highly valued in gold. It is a pity that this mistaken country values only the practical and useful, while the doctrine of fundamental rights in Germany, of the learned professors and attorneys (who, for the sake of science, did not allow even a speaker, let alone a writer, the slightest grammatical mistake or, anything in their view, a formal error) has once again so quickly foundered. My transport from Mr. Kreeft to the exhibition, it almost bordered on a miracle, did not last more than two minutes for 18 kr. This time the omnibus drove on the opposite side of the Serpentine River, which is really only a rather large pond, like one of the smallest Swiss lakes, but which looks very impressive on the beautiful grounds of Hyde park, and pleasure boats with sails and "rigging" of not insignificant size sail around on it. After I had delivered a supplementary manuscript to the office of Professor Wilson, providing details concerning my submission to the exhibition, I re-entered the building. The more one becomes acquainted with it, the more, I would say, one's senses dull to all that one sees and the less one desires to say anything about it, given the absolute impossibility
of any coherent description. Today I had a special purpose. In the entire catalogue, I found only one Damascus sabre listed among the items from Egypt; and in my shipment, there were articles of true Damascus, or as I call it, meteor steel. Unfortunately, my wish to compare the Damascus was not fulfilled, for the sabre was hung too high and, moreover, was still in its sheath. I did see the three Egyptian commissioners, however. Two of them had the mixed features of the Negro and the Caucasian races, both in colour and in the restless, not very congenial gaze. The third, probably an Egyptian German or French, stood out among them, like the modern, silver candelabras among the other, equally precious, genuine Egyptian products in their display. — One of the real Egyptians, (all three of them wore European attire, with the exception of their red hats with black tassels) had a five-pointed golden star on a golden chain, and below it the Turkish crescent, a curious emblem, to which our European diplomats might justifiably take exception. I stayed in the exhibition building until half past six in the evening, without having enjoyed a single thing that morning, but before leaving I viewed quite attentively the celebrated diamond Kooh-i-Noor, or Mountain of Light, which is the property of the East Indian prince
Runject Singh, and whose (presumed) value, judging by the calculation and estimation hitherto used for smaller diamonds, amounts to 2,000,000 L. Sterling, for it would be a shame not to have seen this magnificent jewel the size of Earth, to which, if I were hungry, I would have preferred half a pound of bread. Going by general opinion, everyone is disappointed by this piece, and I would not give a kreuzer to see it again. Even the women, who are otherwise not impervious to diamonds, walk away unmoved. A large rectangular railing encloses a similar pedestal. Inside this railing, which is equipped with a door, there are always two police officers. On the pedestal lies a blue-velvet cushion covered by a large dome-like cage of round, gilded iron bars. On two very small columns, also gilded and barely 6 inches high, rests now in a casing lying diagonally on top of it this wonder of the world, to which neither the foggy atmosphere of London, nor the genius of the English, who otherwise know how to effect many things, could give this white piece of carbon the appearance that (according to the explanation of our chemists) it should have by covering it with boards and gas light. As I said, it was already half past six o'clock. The people employed
in the building for this purpose covered the objects displayed on the stands with cotton cloths, and visitors walked quietly and without crowding towards the doors. Fortunately, among the many thousands hurrying home, I found a spot in an omnibus that took me all the way to Cheapside to an excellent tavern, where I was able to eat enough to make up for my forgotten lunch.

div.head: Fischers Highlights der Ausstellung, 24. Juni 1851
div.p:
June 24th. As an addendum to yesterday’s thoughts on the exhibition, there remains for me, as certainly for many thousands and thousands of visitors, aside from those things of general interest, namely the idea of this undertaking and its splendid execution, only a relatively very small part, for the sake of which I can be pleased to have witnessed this spectacle, for that is what I would like to call it, as regards both objects and people. Four main things, however, will remain in my memory as products of artistic creation. Namely, the portrait of the queen on a life-size porcelain tablet, which Louis Philippe commissioned at the time of theErrata aus Erstdruck. Entente cordiale in Sevres near Paris; then, the large, absolutely flawless mirror made from a single cast, 18 feet high and 10 feet wide; furthermore, the crystal fountain of which I have already made mention. All three of these objects are the greatest triumph of halurgy, to which, to a degree, the porcelainErrata aus Erstdruck. must also be counted, and then, fourthly, the triumph of the
spirit, which controls the elements and natural forces according to its will and shows itself in all its power in the totality of the present machines and locomotives, which even have rails beneath them on which to run and for whose operation only a slight movement of the finger is required to transform its latent energy in the blink of an eye into powerful propulsion. These are the general impressions that can never be gained in such a way anywhere else. Of a thousand and one other things piled up here, the shop floors in great cities, especially in London itself, offer a daily exhibition. One can say entire magazines of luxury articles and precious fabrics are veritable shops of the exhibition, namely glass cases, far larger than those of many stores in reality, where the objects contained therein can be viewed, but not touched. Nothing comes into being in the world at once in all its potency, yet it is astonishing how quickly in the course of time the current needs of society in England are provided for, from which the Englishman, and he is quite right, for this is the only true means of prolonging life, reckons chiefly the profit of time.

Today, because I now had at my disposal every means of transportation required
to do a great deal in less time, I travelled and did business from 10 o'clock in the morning until 4 o'clock in the evening, which astonished even me. — A cab that I hired by the hour, for which I had to pay 1 fl. 24 kr. each, took me first from St. Paul's Church to Finsbury Square to the two Swiss commissioners, from there to the Mint by the Tower, and then to Mr. Kreeft in Billeter Square, and yet, after a rather long conversation with him, I was at London Bridge by 2 o'clock. Since yesterday evening at 3 o'clock, a fire had been raging on the opposite bank, which had broken out in a paper factory and enveloped several hop warehouses. In today's newspapers, the damage to the various insurance companies was already estimated at 200,000 P. Sterling or 240,000 Gulden. Aside from the firemen and the police, no one was bothered about this fire, except to linger a little out of curiosity. It was strange that when the first and second warehouses were burning with a vehemence that made it almost impossible to approach them, and the third warehouse had been saved from the fire completely, that it suddenly broke out in the fourth. The English expression for it was, "It was the fiend who did it," which suggests arson. Fiend is synonymous with Satan. On the banks of the Thames, I purchased a ticket for one of the steamboats leaving every quarter of an hour from London Bridge to Greenwich and
Gravesand, which for the 6 miles to Greenwich cost 4 Pence, or 12 kr. and in half an hour I was there, and a willing Englishman immediately called a carriage driver, who after collecting the tax of a penny (3 kr.), guided me across the very wide Thames, where I arrived in a very short time at the steamship factory of Misters Robinson & Rüssel. At the desk, I asked for Mr. Baird, who, according to his earlier calculations, should have been back in London long ago from Schaffhausen, where he had assembled the steamboat, but this was not the case, as I was able to infer from a letter I received yesterday suggesting that not everything was in order there yet. I found it conspicuous that one of the gentlemen immediately asked me if I was a partner, to which I replied no, I was co-owner of another steamship. After some conversation, which seemed a bit suspicious to me and which did not quite correspond with the remark Mr. Baird once made to me in Schaffhausen, "You are my only friend", I was soon on my way. Again, a boat picked me up at the shore, and in the middle of the ever-turbid Thames, delivered me to the fast steamer Najade for the return trip, whereas the SybilleDie Dampfschiffe Najade und Sybille, die Fischer erwähnt, sind im «Lloyd's Register of British and Foreign Shipping 1850 & 1851» nicht verzeichnet. Dies deutet darauf hin, dass es sich um kleinere, unter 100 Bruttotonnen schwere Themse-Fährdampfer handelte. had brought me. Every quarter of an hour, one is sure to encounter a steamboat going down to Gravesand,
which is 22 miles from the London Bridge, or up to London.

In the evening by 4 o’clock, I was back in my quartersmy quarters. This is the great savings in time I spoke of earlier. Later, I went to a nearby dining establishment, Metropolitan Tavern. In elegance of tableware, it surpassed those at my hotel, and the price of everything, and equally good, was ¼ less than at my lodging, though it only went by the name of tavern, and not hotel.

div.head: Fischer und seine Ausstellungsobjekte, 25. Juni 1851
div.p:
June 25th. This morning I went for the third time to Finsbury Square to our Swiss commissioner Mr. Colladon of Geneva and found him at home. From him I learned that Prof. Bolley, his colleague, had gone home and was unlikely to return. It also seems to me that one commissioner is sufficient, since everything is so well organized, and there is a clerk Steiger from Basel in the glass palace every day, who speaks all three languages, German, English and French, has lived in London for 16 years and canErrata aus Erstdruck. provide any necessary information. A good deal of money could have been spared in Switzerland, but this has probably happened to other governments as well; for the near future, expenditures in England are not to be spared, and the most regrettable thing is that they will hardly benefit those
who made them in any way, neither the governments nor the individuals. Nevertheless, I would have had no occasion for this visit had I not already made the acquaintance of Mr. Colladon 26 years ago at the Swiss Natural Historical Society in Solothurn; incidentally, this is the place to say it, as a Swiss it was also agreeable to him that the little that I contributed to the exhibition was there only by itself. Namely, my Damascus meteor steel and objects made from it, as well as the samples of the alloy of copper and iron in various proportions that I invented, which was previously considered impossible. Be the verdict of the jury of its day what it may, I can testify that I was initially reluctant to send anything to the exhibition, as I considered my achievements in this case too insignificant for a jury that was meant to judge, so to speak, the industry of all four regions of the world, and that I only did so after our first magistrates at the time requested that I do so. They wished to see something to represent the canton and trusted that I would be willing to do so, though I had no hope of success.

From Mr. Colladon I proceeded to my old and highly esteemed friend, Professor Brande, Director of the Stamp Office at the Mint. — The English have a good memory for friendship, this I have
still found to be true. In our conversation about the nature of metals, we both remained static at the boundary that it had so far implacably set for our research. I reiterated my old idea that water in some form or another acts as a bonding agent for metal atoms. I said that I had told him the same thing 25 years agoCompare journal 1825—1827 p. 32 and journal 1846 p. 28. and that he had corrected me when I used the expression water and had noted that it was not water but hydrogen. I now have reason to believe, however, based on my observations that at least another third form than water, which is a compound, and hydrogen, which, on the other hand, is believed to be a simple body, must exist. He neither contradicted nor confirmed, the way the English do, who prefer to be rather too silent than to talk too much, which is the most sensible thing even in politics, where, on the other hand, our beloved youth (jeunesse), who endeavour to improve the world, speak out in volumes, but who, once dependent on the crutch and the armchair, will likely change their tune.

If only I could tap the sources of knowledge that Faraday, Brande, and Liebig have given us! — The alloy invented by me, of which I have already spoken above, and the samples of which I presented to him consisted of 8 parts old iron and 3 parts copper, interested him very much as a chemist,
and it seemed to me that it almost made him disbelieve certain theories contained in the books, since here we have an indisputable fact. He took me into the mint, where he showed me an almost unbelievable break in a press frame of immense thickness and quite sound casting, and then into the water tower, which contains, at a height of 70 feet in an iron basin of 50,000 cubic feet, the best drinking water, drawn from a tapped spring by a steam engine, serving equally well for consumption and to extinguish fires. We also visited the rolling mill. It is almost unbelievable what long sheets of gold lie about waiting to be processed there, or perhaps only understandable, since this little Albion dominates the world far more than Napoleon or his predecessors ever did by conquest.

When I consider, as I write this, that it is only the twelfth day since I left home, that I have travelled through so many countries, have had such a stormy sea voyage, and have already seen so many astonishing things, and think back to the times of my first journey on foot to Basel, in 1787, and how everything was then, bad and narrow roads, only footbridges instead of bridges over the two, often so torrential, forest waters of the Wutach and Steinach, I can hardly recognize myself in the drive that has been given to the human spirit since then: will it continue like this,
where will we end up!? And who will guarantee that the idea does not arise, if the aether be suitable for respiration, or if a surrogate is found, to establish contact with other worlds, which, I might add, the Creator makes quite easy for us through something that is generally avoided like a bitter medicine, namely, through the simple medium of death, "where (as Schiller so beautifully expresses it) the spirit is stripped of the earthly, separates itself in flames from its shell, and drinks the pure air of the aether!"Fischer zitiert in abgeänderter Form Friedrich Schillers Gedicht «Das Ideal und das Leben».

One would have enough to write about in London if limited to only the new things that happen every day, yet they accumulate so quickly as to become immediately obsolete and easily forgotten. Who would not have stopped to watch a burning fire that had already been raging for two days, which, as already mentioned, I myself witnessed yesterday on my way to London Bridge to embark for Greenwich, or rather who would not have watched it for a long time? Yet, as I said, this was not the case. People were going back and forth across London Bridge with their usual alacrity, and I, too, spoke to my fellow passenger on the steamboat about it only as long as we were in its vicinity.

div.head: Fischers Spaziergänge durch London, 26. Juni 1851
div.p:
June 26th. Devoting myself quite early to some business, before intending to go to the exhibition, as the former might lead to some interesting remarks
in the future and confirm that the straightest and clearest path in business always leads most surely to the goal. — If I were a writer of novels, instead of giving an account to myself of the time I have spent, and if I had the talent for it, I could write a rather thick book with truths from my experiences, which would look quite like a novel. So much for all that. Before I went to the exhibition, I was curious to know, since my way led me through Lombard Street, coming from Billeter Square, what had become of my two traveling companions, Captain Hug and Cantonal Councillor Ammann, whom I had only met once by chance in the Crystal Palace, but although they were staying in this street, I could not find the City Hotel. An old woman instructed me to go to St. George’s CourtErrata aus Erstdruck., and there, in the rearmost part of it, was their lodging, called St. George and Vulture, but they had already departed. The building is not so terrible and seems to be frequented mostly by Germans, among whom are probably a number of refugees. In London, however, they do not make their fortune with their beards, just as little as with cigars, and I appeal to all those who have been in London to say whether they have ever encountered a single person out of a thousand people in the street
with a cigar or a pipe in his mouth. Time has too great a value in England for this pastime.

The English commoners have not yet entirely abandoned their intolerance of foreign manners, dress and coiffure. When I worked in London fifty-seven years ago, anyone with foreign attire very soon had what they call "a mob at ones heels", and the honorific name they attached to such an individual was generally "french Dog", insofar as in the great generality the geographical knowledge of this mob extended only to French, and Dutch, inhabitants of France and Holland; but on this day, June 26th 1851, I read in the morning in the eminent newspaper Morning Chronicle, a very general article about the reactionary policy of Austria, in which the large number of troops, which this monarchy still has standing on its feet in the face of gloomy financial conditions, is criticized, but it is partly excused by the political behaviour of Preussen, which is not called by any nice name, and adds that the same (i.e., number of troops) is necessary owing to the garrisons that Austria must keep in its large cities, such as Vienna, Prague, Brixen and Hohenlinden (I read the words for the third time). Incidentally, it is known, insofar as it was published in the newspaper, that, when the Scheldt was opened under his
administration, the great PittSehr wahrscheinlich William Pitt der Ältere. Die Scheldefrage und der Zugang zur Flussmündung für den Handel war eine internationale politische Angelegenheit. Der Zugang zum Fluss war Gegenstand eines kurzen Konflikts während des Kesselkriegs von 1784 und kurz danach während der Französischen Revolution. Im Jahr 1792 wurde der Fluss wieder geöffnet. Es kann aber nicht ausgeschlossen werden, dass sich Fischer auf den Sohn, Pitt den Jüngeren, bezieht. Denn auch zu dessen Amtszeit war die Scheldefrage noch immer aktuell. asked, "where is that d. Escaut?" — Where is that damned Scheldt? Just as in 1814, when I came to England, a customs officer in Dover, to whom I said that I was from Schaffhausen in Switzerland, asked me in all seriousness whether missionaries also visited us. In the diary of my travels at that time, I immediately recorded this question and my answer to it, which can still be found in print. The English hunger for newspapers must be fed every day, and, for the same price, John Bull is fed just as great a variety of stories as a stranger who ventures haphazardly into this or that eating-house in London. To come back to the subject of all manner of foreigners' beards and how repugnant they are, as it seems, to the English commoners, I read on the same day in the newspaper Punch, which otherwise treats no one with mercy, a complaint about the English commoners and their ragamuffins, of whom, by the way, one sees less than in Paris, that they have carried their insolence against Germans with beards so far as to run after them in the vicinity of the exhibition building and to present them with old razors in mockery.
This tendency to imitate the custom of times long past in beards and frumpy old German attire, which good taste rejects, will hardly last long, however.

Many times, as I walked down Lombard Street, a narrow and not very long street, where several bankers and money changers reside, I have stopped in front of the currency exchange house Spielman & Comp., as almost everyone does who has not yet discovered the displays in its windows of large pans, filled mostly with gold and silver and then covered with banknotes and other paper money, and, in addition to these riches, layers of gold bars weighing 4-6 pounds and more. Today, however, I was particularly attracted by a pan of Californian wash gold, and I am certainly not exaggerating when I estimate the weight of gold contained in this pan to be about 40 pounds, and thus worth at least 30,000 Gulden. As gold it is of no interest to me, but immensely so for its form. The general character is as follows: flat, mostly elongated round leaves, approximately as thick as a playing card and even thicker, up to the size of a fingernail. This, however, is not the marvellous thing, but rather the conglomeration, the fusion of these leaflets without any apparent gangue ("Lode"). They can be best compared to the lead flakes that are formed when (in our country at least) young women (sometimes also unmarried older ones) observing the usual traditions, pour liquefied lead into water on St. Andrew's Eve, in order to discern from its shape
whether they will soon find a husband.

I have devoted so much time to studying metals in regard to their formation and destruction, I deliberately use these unscholarly expressions, that I was quite disturbed by the sight of these peculiar formations today. Something else struck me about this gold, namely its reddish, somewhat dingy colour, in contrast to the otherwise solid gold that has accumulated into its natural state, of which I own a beautiful specimen from the Calandaberg in the Grisons.

Following the advice of the synopsis enclosed with the catalogue, I devoted my attention today more to the individual objects of particular interest to me than to wandering around in the extensive halls, looking at everything and seeing nothing, and recorded what I thought worthy of later recollection. In the end, I recorded a far larger inventory than I had assumed and will probably write several pages at another time than at this late hour (half past midnight) about the observations I made.

div.head: Über den englischen Absatzmarkt, 27. Juni 1851
div.p:
June 27th. Today, a full day of business, was a very tiring one for me, although important in its consequences, insofar as I will have to stay in England probably longer than I had intended.
I went first to Mr. Cammell of Sheffield, the largest steel manufacturer in England, whom I had met before, and who, in his conversation with me, declared that his business had expanded to the extent that he was now making 50 tons a week of cement, casting and spring steel, that is, over 1000 Centner. Then I went to Billeter Square near Fenchurch Street and from there to the Phoenix Foundry in Southwark, far across the Thames, where I watched the casting of the bearings (a kind of bushing for the axles of locomotives), consisting of a patented white and soft material, which I know, and discovered some ingenious devices for it. About the properties of these bearings, Mr. Dewrance, the inventor and patent owner, told me that they perform quite well over not too great distances, but turn into a kind of "Decomposition" of black sludge when the friction is sustained for too long a period over great distances, such as from London to Edinburgh.

My business was concluded in a further conversation with Mr. Cammell at his office in Barge Yard, near the Mansion House, whereby I merely remark that only as the English have the whole world as a market for their manufactured goods, their immense turnover makes it possible for them to offer everything so cheaply and, thereby, to crush other
manufacturers, where they are not subjected to tariffs in other countries. For one must know that, for example, in the case of steel production, Mr. Cammell sells his rolled spring steel for 2½ Pence or 7½ Kreuzer of our money. If we assume that he has only half a Kreuzer of pure profit on each pound after deducting all expenses (25 years ago the steel manufacturers in England still calculated a profit on 3 Kreuzer per pound, as Mr. Tailor, then director of the iron and steel works "at the seven Oaks," informed me), then there still remains a net profit of fl. 833 per week, or 40,000 Gulden for the whole year, for large-scale production. Manufacturers on the mainland cannot emulate this, as under no circumstances (I am referring to the production of cast steel here) is it possible to make a profit that even approaches a fiftieth of a percent. Incidentally, what we have just said can be applied to almost all types of products. So much for today. Later, perhaps only after my return, I will come back to this subject.

div.head: Ausflug in die Badeanstalt, 28. Juni 1851
div.p:
June 28th. One often plans to do something in the morning, and by evening, nothing has come of it. Since in England on Saturday afternoon and on Sunday one is to a certain extent quite left to oneself, the freedom to think only of oneself is considerable, and I therefore had in mind for these two days and Monday to head for
Dover, or at least for Brighton, whose seaside resorts are inviting enough in the current heat. However, my business in the morning and writing a letter home in the afternoon delayed my departure in order to reach either of these places in time, so I decided to go to Leicester Square, where I was told there was a bathhouse. From the outside it looks quite respectable, and there are four doors, the first and second for ladies of the first and second classes. A similar partition was provided for the gentlemen. I went to the first class bureau and was given two towels and a coin, marked first class, but I immediately lost all desire to enter when asked to pay no more than six pence (18 Kr.). I was then directed to a narrow gallery, which had equally narrow baths and where about 30 people sat in a queue on benches against the wall, who in the order in which they arrived were directed to a bath as soon as one was vacant. By my calculation, I would have had to wait another 1½ hours, and so I returned my coin and towels, and received, contrary to expectation, my money back. Too overheated from all the walking, I entered a chemist's to drink a jug of natural seltzer water, which, since he told me about it, I followed up with a portion of an artificial one,
which I thoroughly enjoyed for its plentiful carbonation. Regarding it as unhealthy, the "Chemist" was reluctant to give much approval to so-called "Gingerbeer," of which I had already partaken in the morning, as it has an extremely pleasant taste, and which is frequently consumed in summer.

On my way home, I encountered two street sweepers in operation, each of which was drawn by a horse. In these devices, too, which do the work of 20 maids, we see the spirit of the English. On a two-wheeled cart is an oblong wooden box open at the top, at the rear of which, at a suitable distance, an iron axle passes through a cylindrical brush of about 4 feet in length and 2½ to 3 feet in diameter. It has two spur gears that interlock with the spur gears of the same size attached to the inner of the two hubs, so that when the horse advances, the broom, which has just enough slack as to always rest on the street, also rotates from back to front, sweeping the street and pushing the collected matter in front of it. When a quantity of refuse has been collected, the driver stops, scoops it into the box and continues his journey.

As an addendum to my remarks, referring mainly to the metallurgical objects
mentioned at the end of my notes from June 26th, which I was prevented from writing by fatigue and the late hour I would have had to devote to them, I mention, first of all, a collection of East Indian steel, known as "Wootz," from Bombay, and then the unshaped steel blooms from Golconda, which Tavernier mentions in the records of his travels. This wootz consists of small lumps or "Reguli," almost always of the same weight, which were cooled in a crucible. I still possess a fourth of such a lump, which was given to me by Mr. Bréant, Inspecteur des Essais in Paris, in 1826. A whole lump of this kind commonly weighs ⅞ of a pound. This steel is hard, very difficult to forge, it hardens, yet, at least in Europa, does not produce long-lasting cutting instruments. The latest opinion about this steel, albeit erroneous, is that it consists of "magnetic iron". More accurately, one might say it is made of magnetic ironstone. The Golconda lumps are thin and wide, often very porous, and such a lump, which is usually broken into four parts, yields four beautiful Damascus sabre blades, however, often with what the English refer to as "Flaws." I would also mention that this steel is very durable and of excellent quality. Among the stone-cutting tools, I saw a useful device for the hammers, which we call two-pronged hammers, namely steel spikes, which are pointed at the top and bottom and serve two
purposes; they are simply inserted into the iron hammer, which has a rectangular conical hole. If a man has a dozen such spikes, he can work for days without having to run to the blacksmith again, and that is enough for today.

div.head: Weitere Highlights der Ausstellung, 29. Juni 1851
div.p: Sunday, June 29th. In my daily entries, for which I often, even in the height of summer, had to spend hours of the night, I touched on some things only briefly, or not at all, in the hope of mentioning them at a more convenient time. For these things, Sundays in England are quite suitable if one does not travel and, therefore, the following addendum.

I have already remarked in my earlier notes that nothing would be easier than to report something new, or never before seen, every day. Yet, how the various forms of charlatanism, which at bottom is so contrary to the serious and scrutinizing character of the English, though it does not seem to fail in its intended effect and can flourish alongside the genuinely new, good and interesting, is almost incomprehensible and must surely derive from the surprisingly one-sided education of the people. Every day, on my way to the exhibition, in the high streets of London, but especially in Piccadilly, one of the broadest and most beautiful streets of London that leads to Hydepark, I saw six shabby fellows on the sidewalk ("Flags") walking back and forth in procession, one behind the other, all day long.
Each of them carried a large wooden frame attached to a flat pole on the paper cover of which was advertised in large red letters, where one might see a view of the "Holy land" and acquire a faithful image of the city of Jerusalem at the time of our Saviour for 18 kr. (six pence). Anyone who knows the history of the terrible destruction of that city 70 years after Christ (fulfilling the prophecy), as it was handed down to us by Flavius Josephus, would be astonished at such deception of the public. The Rheinau Monastery also boasts such an ancient illustration of Jerusalem, that is, unless it has been stolen from it, like another precious picture book depicting the traditional dress (if I am not mistaken) of the 13th and 14th centuries, at a time when its true owners had no control over their library. However, that illustration is rather more a city plan bearing its location from later times than an illustration like the one above and, in any case, does not bear this presumptuous inscription.

When circa 2000 years ago the famous mathematician Archimedes (whose tomb in Syracuse, already overgrown with weeds, was renovated and restored by the equally famous Cicero, during his time as proconsul in Sicily), after having made the great discovery of the specific gravity of bodies in the bath and, thereby, exposing the fraud of the goldsmith, who substituted alloyed
gold for the pure gold that the king had given him to make the royal crown, repeated his joyful ἑvϱεκα! Korrekte Schreibweise: ηὕρηκα.( I have found it!), he could hardly have imagined that some two thousand years later, in the far north, in the vicinity of Thule, in the tinlands (what is today England) a tailor would adopt his exclamation regarding the men's dress shirts he manufactures, in order, by means of this enigmatic word, to demonstrate to the gullible London public, who are, in fact, not very well versed in the Greek language, that he alone had discovered the one true cut for men's dress shirts. — And, yet it is so — and in several of the coaches, which travel daily to the exhibition, one finds this Greek tailor's pronouncement on a large advertising leaflet. I have already said it repeatedly, and I will say it again, the charlatanry in England is beyond belief, and it seems that they love it for it appears in such great variety.

Indeed, it is astonishing how people in this cosmopolitan city resort to the most incredible things to earn money or to acquire things, and yet the people of the lower classes, despite all manner of industriousness, are not one whit better off than they are in our own country, or rather, not even as well off as those in our own. They have nothing to cultivate. Forests, fields and pastures, not to speak of vineyards,
remain unknown to many, who, it is said, never get out of London their whole lives. Mr. Cammell, who has offices here, as well as in Hamburg and New York, proclaimed with great chagrin upon seeing a coloured illustration of my steelworks in the Mühlenthal: "I want to live there! I'll not stay in London! — The bustle is too great, and nothing but wear and tear." Last week's newspaper reported 870 deaths, and this week's just 100 more, namely 970.

Again, in one of the omnibuses that travel daily to the exhibition, there was a rather large coloured lithograph print at the front, inside, depicting a beautiful young woman and an elder gentleman. Half of the young woman’s hair was in its natural colour, namely an garrish red, while the other half was a glossy raven black, and the gentleman, half of whose hair and Van Dyke beard, was more white than grey, with the other half transformed into a beautiful nut-brown, what the English call "auburn", by virtue of the artistry of the hair dresser, whose address in Picadilly, where he lives, was appended to the lithograph.

My visits to the exhibition on several days
only taught me that, if visiting it is to be of use to anyone with a specific purpose in mind, one must, apart from the most prominent and generally admired objects, turn away completely from the superfluity of what is there and limit oneself only to what can serve this purpose to the greatest extent possible, and that is why I only note, in these leisure hours and later, those things that particularly interested me, as I write first and foremost only for myself, knowing that my family and few friends will gladly make do with what is sufficient for myself. These pages are, as usual, only an account I give myself for the purpose of recollection.

In view of my limited leisure time, I devoted my attention almost exclusively to the mineral, and, in conjunction with these, metallurgical objects and their processing, as well as the machines and tools available for this purpose.
